titleStmt.title: Asynchronous Dissipative Control for Fuzzy Markov Jump Systems

affiliation.orgName: National Laboratory of Industrial Control Technology
College of Electronic and Information Engineering
Chongqing Key Laboratory of Nonlinear Circuits and Intelligent Information Processing

analytic.title: Asynchronous Dissipative Control for Fuzzy Markov Jump Systems

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: The problem of asynchronous dissipative control is investigated for Takagi-Sugeno fuzzy systems with Markov jump in this paper. Hidden Markov model is introduced to represent the nonsynchronization between the designed controller and the original system. By the fuzzy-basis-dependent and modedependent Lyapunov function, a sufficient condition is achieved such that the resulting closed-loop system is stochastically stable with a strictly (Q, S, R)-α-dissipative performance. The controller parameter is derived by applying MATLAB to solve a set of linear matrix inequalities. Finally, we present two examples to confirm the validity and correctness of our developed approach.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: T HE PAST decades have witnessed an increasing popu- larity in Takagi-Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy model since it has powerful capabilities in exactly modeling complicated nonlinear systems via transforming them into a family of local linear subsystems. We can see an overall T-S fuzzy model as a "combination" of these local linear subsystems with fuzzy sets. Plentiful results have been published, such as the filtering design issue [1]- [4], the fuzzy model reduction issue [5], and the fuzzy model identification problem [6]. It has been applied to various fields containing communication networks, biomedicine, and economics. Furthermore, experts have made full use of fuzzy ideas to devise the local controller for corresponding linearized subsystem, which is known as the parallel distributed compensation (PDC) method [7]. Through PDC technique, the guaranteed cost controller has been obtained for continuous-time networked systems in [8].

The work in [9] has studied the robust passive fuzzy control issue where constant delays and sampling intervals have been considered. The quantized tracking issue has been investigated in [10] by the PDC and fuzzy adaptive approaches. Rakkiyappan and Balasubramaniam [11] have analyzed the exponential stability of T-S fuzzy systems with time-varying delays and impulsive effect.

On the other hand, the dissipative theory in view of inputoutput energy-related consideration, first introduced in [12], has become another active research topic in recent years. It relates the generalized energy supply function with internally stored energy, where supplied energy is from the exterior environment and Lyapunov function is analogous to the energy storage function. Dissipative systems only dissipate energy rather than produce it. One important feature of dissipative systems is that the stored energy is less than the supplied energy. Dissipativity contains various basic theories including the circle criterion, bounded real lemma and the passivity theorem. Moreover, dissipative control can be viewed as a unified framework on robust control problems, for example, H ∞ and passivity control criteria are obtained by adjusting parameters (Q, S, R). Hence, it has wide applications in many fields, for instance, chemical processes and electromechanical systems. And fruitful research results have been obtained as well. Kottenstette et al. [13] have intensively investigated the connections among dissipativity, passivity and positive realness for continuous and discrete time-invariant systems, respectively. Researchers in [14] have investigated outputfeedback dissipative control scheme for fuzzy systems, where input delays and output constraints have been taken into consideration. The dissipativity analysis problem has been studied in [15] for fuzzy systems with random perturbation and timevarying delays. The work in [16] and [17] has analyzed the dissipativity issue for neural networks with time delays. The dissipative control problem about time-varying sampling has been discussed in [18] for T-S fuzzy systems.

In addition, practical engineering systems, such as aerospace systems and power engineering systems, often experience abrupt variations resulting from stochastic component failures, unexpected environment disturbance, changes between subsystems, and so on. The Markov jump or Markov chain has been applied to model these complicated phenomena [19]- [24]. Jumps among each subsystem are governed by certain transition probabilities. Researchers have investigated the observebased state feedback control problem for continuous fuzzy systems with Markov jump in [25]. Yin et al. [26] for multiple data-communicating channels for the robust control problem in networked systems. In [27], the homogeneous Markov chain has been applied to stand for random actuator faults for fuzzy systems. Tao et al. [28] have investigated the dissipative mode-dependent controller problem for fuzzy systems with Markov jump. As for Markov jump systems with time-varying delays, the H ∞ control scheme has been developed in [29]. The work in [30] has employed the Markov process to denote the nonuniform sampling and developed the mode-dependent estimator design for fuzzy systems. It is worth noting that [28]- [30] all have assumed that controllers or filters have successful access to the modes of the operational systems such that they keep the same pace with the original systems. However, in fact, it will pay high cost to obtain the sufficient knowledge about the modes. Moreover, due to common existence of adverse factors such as time-varying delays and data dropouts, there is little possibility that they can run synchronously. Therefore, for Markov jump systems, it is essential for us to develop asynchronous controllers or filters. For nonlinear Markov jump systems, Wu et al. [31] have studied the asynchronous filtering problem. The work in [32] has discussed the passivity asynchronous control issue by utilizing hidden Markov models [33]. Up to now, to our best knowledge, there has been no result about the asynchronous dissipative control issue for nonlinear Markov jump systems, which inspires us to fill in this gap. This paper is concerned with the asynchronous (Q, S, R)α-dissipative controller design problem for nonlinear Markov jump systems. First, T-S fuzzy inference method is exploited to model the nonlinear systems. A fuzzy asynchronous controller is constructed via applying the PDC approach and hidden Markov models. We apply the Lyapunov function to achieve a sufficient condition, which ensures that stochastic stability of the closed-loop system with strict dissipativity performance. Moreover, the desired dissipative controller parameter can be obtained via MATLAB toolbox. Finally, two examples are provided to show the validity of our proposed results. The primary contributions of this paper are as follows.

1) In contrast with some published papers such as [15]- [18], it is the first time that the problem of strictly dissipative asynchronous controller for T-S fuzzy systems with Markov jump is investigated.

2) The fuzzy-basis-dependent and mode-dependent Lyapunov function approach and the slack matrix technique are utilized to transform a nonlinear problem into linear convex optimization one, which reduce the conservatism.

3) The obtained approach is more general because it can be applied to design other kinds of controllers including mode-independent, synchronous, passive, and H ∞ controllers. The remaining parts are planed as follows. The problem formulation and some preliminaries are illustrated in Section II. Section III investigates conditions to satisfy the stability and dissipativity of the closed-loop system as well as the asynchronous controller design technique. Two examples are demonstrated in Section IV and Section V draws the conclusion of this paper.

div.head: Notation:
div.p: The notations utilized in this paper are standard. R n represents the n-dimensional Euclidean space. P > 0 (<0) means the Matrix P is symmetric positive-definite (negativedefinite). We apply an asterisk ( * ) to stand for a symmetric term in a matrix. λ min (•) is the minimal eigenvalue of a matrix. The superscript "T" represent a matrix transposition. diag(•) denotes a block-diagonal matrix. • denotes the Euclidean vector norm and E{•} is the expectation of a value.

div.head: II. PRELIMINARY ANALYSIS
div.p: For a probability space ( , F, P), consider the following nonlinear Markov jump systems, described via T-S fuzzy approach.
Plant Rule i:
div.formula: IF ϑ 1k is η i1 , ϑ 2k is η i2 , and • • • and ϑ lk is η il , THEN x k+1 = A r k i x k + B 1r k i u k + D 1r k i w k z k = C r k i x k + B 2r k i u k + D 2r k i w k (1
div.p: where i ∈ I = {1, 2, . . . , r} is the ith fuzzy rule and r is the total number of rules; ϑ jk (j ∈ {1, 2, . . . , l}) is the premise variable; η ij is the fuzzy set.
div.formula: x k ∈ R n is the state variable; u k ∈ R m is the control input; and z k ∈ R p is the controlled output and w k ∈ R o is the external disturbance which belongs to l 2 [0, +∞). A r k i , B 1r k i , B 2r k i , C r k i , D 1r k i ,
Pr{r k+1 = t|r k = s} = π st , s, t ∈ M. (2
div.p: It is easy to find that 0 ≤ π st ≤ 1 and M t=1 π st = 1. Through the T-S fuzzy inference, the overall considered system with r k = s is inferred as
div.formula: x k+1 = A sh x k + B 1sh u k + D 1sh w k z k = C sh x k + B 2sh u k + D 2sh w k (3
div.p: where
div.formula: A sh = r i=1 h i (ϑ k )A si , C sh = r i=1 h i (ϑ k )C si B 1sh = r i=1 h i (ϑ k )B 1si , B 2sh = r i=1 h i (ϑ k )B 2si D 1sh = r i=1 h i (ϑ k )D 1si , D 2sh = r i=1 h i (ϑ k )D 2si ϑ k = ϑ 1k , ϑ 2k , . . . , ϑ lk , h i (ϑ k ) = l j=1 η ij (ϑ jk ) r i=1 l j=1 η ij (ϑ jk )
div.p: The variable η ij (ϑ jk ) represents the grade of membership ϑ jk in η ij ; h i (ϑ k ) is the normalized fuzzy weighting function. Here, we suppose that l j=1 η ij (ϑ jk ) > 0. It easily follows that:
div.formula: h i (ϑ k ) ≥ 0, r i=1 h i (ϑ k ) = 1. (4
div.p: For notational brevity, h i (ϑ k ) is described as h i in the later section.
In this paper, by PDC approach, fuzzy asynchronous statefeedback controller is devised as follows.
Controller Rule i:
div.formula: IF ϑ 1k is η i1 , ϑ 2k is η i2 , and • • • and ϑ lk is η il , THEN u(k) = K δ k i x(k) (5
div.p: where K δ k i ∈ R m×n is the ith local state-feedback controller parameter to be determined. δ k has the same effect as r k , taking values in N = {1, 2, . . . , N} and satisfying the conditional probability matrix = {ϕ sv } with
div.formula: Pr{δ k = v|r k = s} = ϕ sv , s ∈ M, v ∈ N (6)
div.p: where N v=1 ϕ sv = 1 and 0 ≤ ϕ sv ≤ 1. Then, under δ k = v, it follows that:
div.formula: u(k) = K vh x(k) (7
div.p: where
div.formula: K vh = r i=1 h i K vi .
div.p: Remark 1: Motivated by Wu et al. [32] and Rabiner [33], we employ a hidden Markov model to stand for the asynchronous circumstances between the original system (3) and the controller (7). The asynchronous modes are obtained by observing the studied system modes. However, the nonsynchronous mode in [31] and [34] is up to not only the mode of the original plant at time k but also the mode of designed controller or filter at time k -1. In this paper, nonsynchronous mode is only dependent on the mode of the original plant at time k and has nothing to do with modes at time k -1 or k + 1.

Remark 2: It is necessary to mention that the designed asynchronous controller (7) contains two special cases. If M = N and ϕ ss = 1 in (6), the controller (7) turns into a mode-dependent controller, which has been investigated in [28]. If N = 1, it becomes a mode-independent controller without taking the original modes into consideration.
The following closed-loop fuzzy system is achieved by combining system (3) and asynchronous controller (7):
div.formula: x k+1 = Āsvh x k + D 1sh w k z k = Csvh x k + D 2sh w k (8
div.p: where
div.formula: Āsvh = A sh + B 1sh K vh = r i=1 r j=1 h i h j Āsvij Csvh = C sh + B 2sh K vh = r i=1 r j=1 h i h j Csvij Āsvij = A si + B 1si K vj , Csvij = C si + B 2si K vj D 1sh = r i=1 h i (ϑ k )D 1si , D 2sh = r i=1 h i (ϑ k )D 2si .
div.p: The following quadratic energy supply rate for input-output pairs (w k , z k ) in the system (8) is described as:
div.formula: r(z k , w k ) = z T k Qz k + 2z T k Sw k + w T k Rw k . (9
div.p: Here Q, S, and R are given real matrices; R satisfies R T = R; and Q is negative semidefinite matrices, which implies that 9), we obtain the quadratic energy supply function for the system (8) in the following:
div.formula: -Q = Q T -Q -. From (
J(z k , w k , T) = T k=0 E{r(z k , w k )}. (10
div.p: The following definition is introduced to facilitate investigation later.
Definition 1 [35]: If for any T > 0, under zero initial condition, the following inequality holds:
div.formula: J(z k , w k , T) > 0 (11
div.p: the system ( 8) is said to be (Q, S, R)-dissipative regarding the supply rate (9). Moreover, if for a given scalar α > 0 and any T > 0, under zero initial condition, the following inequality holds:
div.formula: J(z k , w k , T) > α T k=0 w T k w k (12
div.p: the system ( 8) is said to be strictly (Q, S, R)-α-dissipative regarding the supply rate ( 9) and α is the dissipativity performance bound.
The major purpose of this paper is to devise the controller (7) guaranteeing that the closed-loop system (8) satisfies the following.
1) The system (8) is stochastically stable when w k ≡ 0, that is
2) Under zero initial condition, the system (8) is strictly (Q, S, R)-α-dissipative.

div.head: III. MAIN RESULTS
div.p: In the section, a sufficient condition will be first presented to prove the stability and strict dissipativity of the system (8) on the assumption that controller gain K vi is known. Then, we will focus on the K vi design for the system (8).
Theorem 1: If there exist matrices P si > 0 and W svi > 0 for any s ∈ M, v ∈ N and a, i, j ∈ I subject to N v=1 ϕ sv W svi < P si (14) svaii < 0 (15
div.formula: ) svaij + svaji < 0, i < j (16
div.p: then the system (8) is stochastically stable and strictly (Q, S, R)-α-dissipative. where

div.p: Owing to P th + = r a=1 h + a P ta and P ta > 0, the following inequalities are obtained by Schur complement:

div.formula: ψ 1svh = Āsvh D 1sh , ψ 2svh = Csvh D 2sh ψ 3svh = -W svh -CT svh S * 22 , X sh + = M t=1 π st P th + .

div.p: Construct the following Lyapunov function:
div.formula: V k = x T k P sh x k . (24
div.p: Along the system (8) with w k ≡ 0, we have
div.formula: E{ V k } = E x T k+1 P th + x k+1 -EL x T k P sh x k = x T k N v=1 ϕ sv ĀT svh X sh + Āsvh -P sh x k . (25
div.p: Recalling ( 22), we acquire
div.formula: E{ V k } < -λ min - N v=1 ϕ sv ĀT svh X sh + Āsvh + P sh x T k x k < -βx T k x k < 0 (26
div.p: where
div.formula: β = inf λ min - N v=1 ϕ sv ĀT svh X sh + Āsvh + P sh , s ∈ M .
div.p: From k = 0 to ∞, summing up the inequality of both sides, we have
According to ( 13), ( 27) implies that the system (8) is stochastically stable.
As for the supply rate (9), we have
div.formula: E V k -r(z k , w k ) + αw T k w k = ζ T k N v=1 ϕ sv ψ T 1svh X sh + ψ 1svh -ψ T 2svh Qψ 2svh + ψ 3svh ζ k (28
div.p: where
div.formula: ζ k = x T k w T k T .
div.p: From k = 0 to T, summing up both side and recalling (10) and ( 23), we obtain that
div.formula: V T+1 -V 0 -J(z k , w k , T) + α T k=0 w T k w k < 0. (29
div.p: With zero initial condition, namely, V 0 = 0, it follows that:
div.formula: J(z k , w k , T) > α T k=0 w T k w k + V T+1 > α T k=0 w T k w k . (30
div.p: According to Definition 1, we have that the system (8) is strictly (Q, S, R)-α-dissipative. The proof is finished. Remark 3: The fuzzy-basis-independent Lyapunov function has been adopted in [18] for the dissipative fuzzy controller design problem. However, in this paper, Lyapunov function V k used in Theorem 1 is not only fuzzy-basis-dependent, but also mode-dependent, which means it can flexibly change with jump modes and fuzzy rules, and bring out less conservatism in spite of computational increase. On the other hand, a nonmonotonic Lyapunov function approach has been investigated in [36] for uncertain T-S fuzzy systems. This means that V k does not decrease monotonically with time, i.e., V k+1 < V k , which needs our further study.

Remark 4: From energy dissipativity aspect, V k is the internally stored energy function of a system, and J(z k , w k , T) is regarded as the supplied energy from external environment with the supply rate r(z k , w k ) from time 0 to T. If the supplied energy by r(z k , w k ) is more than the stored energy inside a system, the system is said to be dissipative [12].
In the following, we will investigate the control design method for the controller gain K vi in (7) based on Theorem 1.

div.p: then the system ( 8) is stochastically stable and strictly (Q, S, R)-α-dissipative. Moreover, the controller gain in ( 7) can be obtained as
div.formula: K vj = Kvj G -1 v (34
div.p: where
div.formula: Psi = Psi √ ϕ s1 √ ϕ s2 . . . √ ϕ sN Wsvi = diag{ Ws1i , Ws2i , . . . , WsNi } svaij = ⎡ ⎢ ⎢ ⎣ 11 -T 12 S T 12 Q T - T 14 * 22 D T 2si Q T - T 24 * * -I 0 * * * -44 ⎤ ⎥ ⎥ ⎦ 11 = Wsvi -G v -G T v 12 = C si G v + B 2si Kvj 22 = -R + αI -D T 2si S -S T D 2si 44 = diag{ P1a , P2a , . . . , PMa } 14 = ⎡ ⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎣ √ π s1 (A si G v + B 1si Kvj ) √ π s2 (A si G v + B 1si Kvj ) . . . √ π sM (A si G v + B 1si Kvj ) ⎤ ⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎦ 24 = ⎡ ⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎣ √ π s1 D 1si √ π s2 D 1si . . . √ π sM D 1si ⎤ ⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎦ -Q = Q T -Q -.
div.p: Proof: Owing to Wsvi > 0, the following inequality is obtained by Schur complement:
div.formula: N v=1 ϕ sv Psi W-1 svi PT si < Psi (35

div.p: Via pre-and post-multiplying P-1 si to (35), we obtain ( 14), which means ( 31) is equivalent to (14).

Together with Wsvi = W -1 svi , we obtain that

div.formula: 2 svaii < 0 (39
div.p: where
div.formula: 2 svaii = ⎡ ⎢ ⎢ ⎣ 11 -T 12 S T 12 Q T - T 14 * 22 D T 2si Q T - T 24 * * -I 0 * * * -44 ⎤ ⎥ ⎥ ⎦ 11 = -G T v W svi G v . Through premultiplying diag{G -T
div.p: v , I, I, I} and postmultiplying diag{G -1 v , I, I, I} to (39), respectively, we have (15) with consideration of Kvj = K vj G v . It means that ( 32) is sufficient for (15). Adopting the similar proof process, we will clearly find out that ( 16) can be deduced from (33). Furthermore, if there is a solution to ( 31)-( 33), the controller gain in (7) will be inferred as
div.formula: K vj = Kvj G -1
div.p: v . The proof is finished.

Remark 5: In ( 15) and ( 16), it is quite difficult to obtain the controller gain K vj because of nonlinear terms like P 1a Āsvij ( Āsvij = A si + B 1si K vj ), where P 1a and K vj needs determining. To overcome this issue, we introduce a mode-dependent slack matrix G v and apply the relaxation approach in (38) to simplify a complicated nonlinear control problem into the feasibility of a set of linear matrix inequalities (LMIs), which can be solved by LMI toolbox in MATLAB.

Remark 6: Theorem 2 presents a sufficient condition to guarantee that the system ( 8) is stochastically stable with strictly (Q, S, R)-α-dissipative performance criterion in the form of LMIs. The optimal dissipative performance α * and (Q, S, R)-α * -dissipative controller (7) can be achieved via solving a convex optimization problem min -α s.t. ( 31)- (33).
Remark 7: It is necessary to note that the achieved results can be extended into two special cases.

1) H ∞ performance by letting Q = -I, S = 0, and R = (α 2 + α)I in ( 32) and (33). 2) Passivity performance by letting Q = 0, S = I, and R = 2αI in (32) and (33). In addition, in Theorem 2, if I = 1 which means no fuzzy rules with Q = 0, S = I, and R = 2αI, the passivity issue has been studied in [32].

div.head: IV. ILLUSTRATIVE EXAMPLES
div.p: In this section, we provide two examples to illustrate the correctness of our obtained results. Example 1 presents three-kind asynchronous fuzzy controller design including dissipative, H ∞ , and passive controllers. In Example 2, we will show how the conditional probability matrix impacts the system performance and compare our approach with an alternative method.
Example 1: The matrices of the system (3) are given in the following:
We assume that modes of the system (3) and controller (7), shown in Fig. 1, obey the following transition and conditional probability matrices:
The disturbance is supposed to be
It is obviously to observe the open-loop system (3) is unstable from Fig. 2 with x(0) = 0.5 -0.5 T .

1) Dissipative Control: Setting Q = -0.2, S = -3, and R = 4. Via solving LMIs ( 31)-( 33), the optimal controller parameters are derived and the optimal α * for the strictly dissipative performance is 2.3481. 2) H ∞ Control:
div.formula: Setting Q = -1, S = 0, R = α 2 +
div.p: α. Via solving LMIs ( 31)-( 33), the optimal controller parameters are derived
div.formula: Setting Q = 0, S = 1, R = 2α.
div.p: Via solving LMIs ( 31)-( 33), the optimal controller parameters are derived and the optimal α * for passive performance is 0.1385. For different performance indexes (dissipativity, H ∞ , and passivity ), Figs. 345present state responses in the corresponding control inputs, respectively. We can clearly find that the state responses tend to zero with time passing by. These results confirm the correctness of our developed technique.
Example 2: A single link robot arm system [28], [29], [37], described by the following continuous-time dynamic differential equation:
div.formula: ẋ1 (t) = x 2 (t) ẋ2 (t) = - glM rt J rt sin(x 1 (t)) -R J rt x 2 (t) + 1 J rt u(t) + w(t) (40
div.p: where g is the gravity acceleration, R is the coefficient of the viscous friction, and l is the arm length. Their values are, respectively, g = 9.81, R = 2, and l = 0.5. M r t and J r t are the payload mass and inertia moment, varying with Markov jump r t , shown in Fig. 6 Values M r t and J r t are shown in Table I. Apply the first-order Euler approximation technique to discretize the system (40) with T = 0.1. Then via using the T-S fuzzy inference approach to approximate the discretized system, the normalized fuzzy weighting function is set as
where x 1 (k) ∈ (-π, π) and β = 10 -2 /π .
div.formula: : IF x 1 (k) is about 0 rad, THEN x k+1 = A r k 1 x k + B 1r k 1 u k + D 1r k 1 w k z k = C r k 1 x k + B 2r k 1 u k + D 2r k 1 w k . div.p: We assume that the conditional probability matrix of Markov jump δ k , as shown in Fig. 6 By solving LMIs ( 31)-( 33) via MATLAB, we obtain the controller gains are In simulation, we assume that initial condition is x(0) = [0.3π -0.1] T , and the external disturbance is and from Fig. 8(a), it is easy to find out the state trajectories approximate to zero as time k goes by. By calculating, the optimal α for the strictly dissipative performance is 0.4696.

w k = e -0.

div.head: A. Effects of on the System Performance
div.p: We will investigate what impacts the different conditional probability matrices have on the performance of systems for various control issues, namely, dissipative, H ∞ , and passive performance. The values are shown in Table II. Then, we acquire the optimal performance α * by solving a set of LMIs in Theorem 2 together with adjusting parameter values Q, S, and R, presented at Table III. Based on Table IV, it is clear to find that the H ∞ and passive performances have similar trend: the higher the synchronization level is, the smaller the optimal performance α * is. However, the tendency of dissipative criterion is opposite.

div.head: B. Comparison Between Our Approach and Alternative One
div.p: The alternative approach is derived by choosing Psi as Ps , that is, the Lyapunov function matrix becomes a fuzzy-basis-independent but mode-dependent one. From Table V, it is evident that the number of variables of our technique needing solving is more than that of the alternative one. However, our method demonstrates a better performance than the alternation since α * solved by our approach is bigger than that of alternative one. If we apply common Lyapunov function matrix Psi as P which has been used in [18]. Though this method has fewer unknown variables, there is no feasible result in Theorem 2. It is a tradeoff between computation complexity and conservatism. In this paper, to obtain less conservatism, we adopt mode-dependent and fuzzy-basis-dependent Lyapunov function instead of only mode-dependent or common one.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, the strictly (Q, S, R)-α-dissipative asynchronous controller problem has been investigated for T-S fuzzy systems with Markov jump. We have proposed a sufficient condition to guarantee that the closed-loop system is stochastically stable with (Q, S, R)-α-dissipative performance via the Lyapunov function technique. The optimal dissipative performance and the corresponding asynchronous controller can be achieved via solving a convex optimization issue. Finally, two examples have been shown to illustrate the effectiveness of our obtained approach. In the future, we can extend our obtained results to more general and complex systems, for instance, continuous-time nonlinear networked control systems with nonhomogeneous Markov jump and time-varying delay communication systems with stochastic perturbation. Besides, it will be a meaningful research topic to apply the nonmonotonic Lyapunov function approach to design an asynchronous controller or filter rather than the monotonic Lyapunov function method.
